16.text: My name's Clifford Stott, and my area of research

19.text: focuses on the social psychology of crowd behaviour.

27.text:
You've only got to look to the Arab Spring
and look to Ukraine to understand the significance

32.text:
of what crowd events can become. People get
arrested, people get criminalised,

36.text:
police careers can end in an instant,
because of decisions that are made.

43.text:
The work that I do began with an ESRC-funded
studentship back in 1989, and through that

51.text:
work we began to understand that much of the
conflict that we were witnessing in our research

56.text:
was brought about by particularly aggressive
forms of policing that set in motion dynamics

62.text:
of escalation in a crowd, creating the psychology
of a riot. Police would wheel out the riot squad

68.text:
to show that they had the capacity to
control these crowds. And we fundamentally

74.text:
changed that, because what we've shown is
that actually crowd dynamics involve the perception

79.text:
of the legitimacy of policing action. And
those policing practices are not based around

83.text:
deterrence and fear, they're based around
engagement and dialogue.

92.text:
Through the work that we were doing we were
producing results that then enabled us to

96.text:
affect the security planning for the European
Championships in Portugal in 2004.

102.text:
And once we'd achieved that impact on policy we were
in a position to apply to the ESRC to generate

109.text:
funds to conduct a major study of the policing
of that tournament, and the implications of

116.text: that policing on crowd psychology and behaviour.

119.text: They've developed these new units - Police Liaison

121.text:
Teams or Police Liaison Officers - and
from the outset, from planning an operation

126.text:
onwards, they have relationships with people
in the crowd that they can negotiate solutions

132.text:
to those problems that mean it's much less
likely that the police will need or actually

138.text:
deploy units that might then use force,
such as dispersal

143.text: or what has come to be referred to as 'kettling'.

147.text:
What Cliff's research has helped us do is
engage with protest groups, particularly protest

151.text:
leaders, in a much more constructive way,
which means we need far fewer resources and

156.text:
it's more peaceful and more constructive,
and also helps us hold on to the support

160.text:
and consent of the majority on those difficult
protests when you get a challenging small

165.text: group trying to whip it up into violence.

167.text:
The rest of the crowd understand it and we
don't get a 'domino effect', if you like, where

174.text:
it starts as a small localised incident, the
rest of the protest see it as something else,

179.text:
and as a result we then get significant conflict
between police and the protest groups.

185.text:
We've now seen these reforms in policy, the
training for public order commanders nationally

190.text:
has been fundamentally reformed so all public
order commanders now get some input about

196.text: this crowd psychology, and about this research.

199.text:
We have about 60 or so Police Liaison Officers
which has emerged directly from Cliff's research.

206.text:
We have a dedicated sergeant and three constables,
we call them the Police Liaison Gateway Team,

209.text:
and as the name suggests they are the gateway
to negotiation and dialogue with all protest

214.text:
groups. A protest group notifies us they're
going to have a protest, the PLT Gateway Team

219.text:
will be the ones who will then engage with
them in the first instance, try and build

222.text:
up that relationship, that rapport, and then
we will deploy Police Liaison Team officers

227.text:
on the ground when the protest or the gathering
or whatever it happens to be, actually takes place.

232.text:
This has helped spark other officers to think
about how could they use research and collaboration

237.text:
with academia in a different way - because
we need practical solutions we can deploy,

241.text:
rather than a theoretical paper five years
later - and that's what Cliff's done for us.
